MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.32 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961].

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a

Column: 524

merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.".- (The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim).

Which Amendment was,

    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day".'-(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

2.33 p.m.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I said yesterday that it would be relevant to the merger issue to find out (a) exactly when the Barisan Sosialis decided that the P.A.P. merger plan on the basis of autonomy in education and labour should be branded as phoney and a sell-out; and (b) when the puppet masters who manipulate the Barisan Sosialis decided on the new line of full merger on the basic of automatic Federal citizenship for Singapore citizens.

    If you recollect, Sir, I quoted a letter from Mr Lim Ching Siong, dated 24th June, in which he indicated that merger should not involve a setback for the people not only in terms of freedom and democracy but also as regards autonomy in labour and education. He did not then (i.e., 24th June) brand the P.A.P.'s demand for merger on the basis of autonomy in labour and education as phoney or a sell-out.

    As far as we can determine, Sir, the constitutional stand of the Barisan Sosialis leaders in June was internal self-government, not merger, because they then believed, presumably on the basis of consultation and clarification with the U.K. Commission, that the P.A.P. type of merger would not be acceptable to the Federation and that, therefore, the P.A.P. would have no choice but to fight for full internal self-government and the abolition of the I.S.C., which are the aims not only of the Barisan Sosialis, but as I shall show later, of the M.C.P. That was the constitutional stand of the Barisan Sosialis in June and July.

Column: 525



    However on 25th August, the Singapore and Federation Governments issued a joint statement agreeing to merger on the basis of autonomy in education and labour. The Barisan Sosialis prophets and Brains Trust discovered that they had miscalculated - and not for the first time either. They had miscalculated in taking an uncompromising stand on the basis of fighting for full internal self-government. What they believed improbable and impossible had happened. Therefore, as I have said, Sir, there was a state of befuddlement, which was exemplified, as I indicated yesterday, in the "Declaration of meeting of convenors of the Barisan Sosialis", dated 3rd September. Things had moved so fast that they were not quite sure what was happening. They knew there was a race on, but they did not know who were in the race or what the race was all about. Therefore, in the declaration under the heading, "Our stand on the constitutional future", they decided that the safest thing under the circumstances was to back as many horses as possible. So, Sir, under the heading, "Our stand on the constitutional future" they declared that the way ahead, therefore, for a real reunification of our people and of our country is in one of two directions:

    (a) immediate full and complete merger with Singapore joining the Federation as a constituent State, like Penang or Malacca;

    (b) as an autonomous unit within a confederation with the Borneo territories coming in when possible."

    Sir, in June the Barisan Sosialis was not yet formed, but it was already a twinkle in the eyes of its parents. In June, Sir, it was internal self-government minus the I.S.C. - a negation of merger. But after it became obvious that merger on the basis of autonomy in labour and education was possible, the gentlemen of the Barisan Sosialis did a triple somersault and fell fiat on their faces.

    Sir, if they had stopped short of what they suggested was one of two courses - immediate, full and complete merger with Singapore joining the Federation as a constituent State like Penang and Malacca: or (it does not matter what it is) an autonomous unit within a confederation with the Borneo territories coming in when possible - then we,

Column: 526

however much we might have disagreed with the Barisan Sosialis, would never have called into question whether they are for or against merger. We would have said that at least, however badly they miscalculated when they left the P.A.P., they did not miscalculate the trend of political events in Singapore. But, Sir, immediately after all these professions of enthusiasm for merger and confederation, they go on, in the last paragraph entitled "Conclusion", - after a long rigmarole, we are now presented with the "Conclusion". Having said that there are two courses for Singapore - complete merger, or confederation, they conclude - nothing. I think this is a classic example of how the thinking of the leaders of the Barisan Sosialis differs from ordinary mortals. Having said that there are two courses open - complete merger or confederation, they conclude, and I will read, Sir:

    "The immediate task, therefore, is to acquire the right of self-determination and achieve full internal self-government."

    That is the conclusion. The logic is this. The way ahead is in one of two directions - complete merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca, or confederation. Therefore, we conclude that the Barisan Sosialis should fight for internal self-government. Full merger is good; confederation is good; therefore, let us fight not for merger or confederation, but for internal self-government and the abolition of the I.S.C. This, perhaps the Members of the Barisan Sosialis would claim, is the logic higher dialectical materialism, a classic example of progress -

    Dr Sheng Nam Chim (Nee Soon) rose -

    Mr Speaker: On a point of order?

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Yes, Sir. I think the Minister for Culture is deliberately misquoting the document. My contention is that in that document we stated that there are three courses.

    Mr Speaker: Order. If there is any quotation of a document out of context, then all the hon. Member need say is that there is a quotation out of context and indicate how it is out of context. The Minister will then be asked to read

Column: 527

the whole paragraph or any other paragraph indicated by the Member. He is now entering into a debate which, of course, he will have the opportunity to do when he speaks.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister's contention is that the first is good, the second is good, but let us fight for the third. That is a misrepresentation of that Conclusion.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Is the Member alleging that the quotations are out of context and so have a different meaning? If he alleges that, then will he indicate which paragraphs he requires the Minister to read? The Member is now entering into a debate.

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: I will just ask the Minister for Culture to read the whole of the last paragraph.

    Mr Speaker: The whole of the last paragraph, Mr Minister.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, the last paragraph reads "Forward with Barisan Sosialis - Merdeka!" [Interruption].

    Mr Speaker: Order. Will the Minister please let me have the document?

    Copy of document handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Member for Nee Soon means the whole of that part of the document under the heading "6. Conclusion".

    Dr Sheng Nam Chin: Under 5. When I was quoting I was doing so without the pamphlet, but from memory only.

    Mr Speaker: That is much too long an extract. If the Minister would read the whole of the "Conclusion", I think that would probably sum up the whole of the conclusion, including "Forward with Barisan Sosialis -Merdeka!".

    Copy of document handed hack to the Minister for Culture.

    Mr Speaker: I think the Member for Nee Soon will have the opportunity later on of contradicting what the Minister has said. Mr Minister.

Column: 528



    Mr Rajaratnam: The "Conclusion" reads:

    'The immediate task, therefore, is to acquire the right of self-determination and achieve full internal self-government. To achieve this, we must strive for the unity of our people. As a Left-Wing political Party, we must join hands with all genuine Left-Wing forces. Only this way can we satisfy the legitimate expectations of the people.

    Forward with the Barisan Sosialis - Merdeka!'

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, as far as I can gather - and as any reasonable man can gather - the logic is that there is one of two ways: merger or confederation, and that therefore the immediate task is to fight for something which is opposite of the two, and that is full internal self-government. This is very much like the young and nervous lawyer who concluded his speech to the jury with the words, "Gentlemen, these then are the conclusions on which I base my facts." The Member for Queenstown took 7½ hours to tell us the conclusions on which he based his facts. We discovered that when he concluded his speech on Tuesday. After saying that he was for merger and that he was prepared to sacrificed not only Mr Lim Ching Siong but possibly also the 12 or 13 other anxious Members in this Assembly in the cause of merger, he said. "But if all this fails, let us fight for full internal self-government minus the Internal Security Council." So far as we can determine. on 3rd September, the stands of the Barisan Sosialis on the constitutional future were complete merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca, confederation, and full internal self-government minus the I.S.C. Like the Scarlet Pimpernel, they were here, there and everywhere. They were animal, vegetable and mineral. They were atheists, monotheists and pantheists. They could not possibly go wrong - so they thought. The ways of mice and men!

    On 21st September, one of their stands collapsed. It had to be abandoned. This was their stand on full and complete merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca. The tragedy - if I may so call it - occurred in the course of a radio

Column: 529

forum in which the Member for Queenstown participated - together with the Member for Farrer Park and. I believe, the Member for Hong Lim - prompted. I have no doubt, more by valour than discretion. There he discovered to his horror that merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca would have meant that only about half of Singapore's citizens would automatically qualify for Federal citizenship.

    Since then, I understand that the Member for Queenstown has developed a kind of phobia about radio forums. Perhaps it is not the Member for Queenstown so much as his colleagues who sweat at the thought of having to let him loose at radio forums.

    Sir, after this disastrous radio encounter, the demand for full and complete merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca - I repeat on the basis of Penang and Malacca - was quietly dropped but was heard all around. Everybody knew. Just as the late Mr Stalin was disinterred and buried outside the grounds of the Kremlin, so did this Party pillar vanish from the hymn book of the Barisan Sosialis. Since then, the Barisan Sosialis choir has rearranged the merger music. We hear, Sir, more and more about something called Article 22 and, of course, automatic Federal citizenship.

    We had a rendering of this new choral arrangement from the robust throat of the Member for Queenstown for the best part of 7½ hours.

    So today the new tune, the new line is automatic Federal citizenship for all Singapore citizens. As I explained yesterday, Sir, this demand for automatic Federal citizenship is being put forward not with a view to enhancing the prospects for merger, but to make sure that merger does not come about, so that we would be forced to adopt the true and only objective of the real leaders of the Barisan Sosialis - a self-governing Singapore minus the I.S.C.

    Sir, if the Barisan Sosialis leaders are genuinely determined to achieve merger, then let them repudiate, without any qualification, their objective of internal self-government for Singapore, because internal self-government is a complete negation of the objective of merger. If

Column: 530

they are really for merger, if they claim that they are interested in the reunification of the two territories, and if they claim that they are in the mainstream of Malayan nationalism, then let them say that internal self-government is not their objective under any circumstances. If they are prepared to do that, then on this side of the House, many people, many Malayan nationalists will not taunt them by saying that they are not sincere when they ask for merger.

    In other words, the Barisan Sosialis should really stick to section 5 of the declaration that the way ahead for a real reunification of our people and territories is in one of two directions-full merger with Singapore joining the Federation as a constituent State or a Confederation. Let them put forward two choices both of which would lead to merger, but not three. Therefore, I propose that the three points the Barisan Sosialis should consider are - merger as outlined in the White Paper proposals; merger as put forward by them on the basis of automatic Federal citizenship; and repudiation of full internal self-government with the T.S.C. abolished. Then the choice will be not between merger and no merger, but between different kinds of merger. That is the true choice. That is the choice of anyone who claims to be a Malayan nationalist and who claims to be interested in the reunification of the two territories. Scrap this constant demand which boils down to this: let us have full internal self-government minus the I.S.C. In fact, that is a choice which every Socialist and nationalist repudiates as unbecoming. dangerous and anti-nationalistic. Let us therefore put forward the two choices to the people for their consideration: merger as outlined in the White Paper -

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Phoney merger!

    Mr Rajaratnam: - or merger as demanded by the Barisan Sosialis with automatic Federal citizenship for all. If that is the choice - we for our own part believe that our proposals will be acceptable to the Federation and to the people of Singapore - if the Barisan Sosialis believe, as they say, that it is a phoney merger, well and good. [Interruption]

Column: 531



    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Let them put forward their proposal of merger on the basis of automatic Federal citizenship with no rider, that "If we cannot get merger, then let us go back to full internal self-government." Everytime they say that, they are giving the game away.

    As I said yesterday, Sir, there is nothing wrong in principle in the Barisan Sosialis asking for automatic Federal citizenship, or for more seats in the Federal Legislature, or for any other conditions which they think are favourable and acceptable to the people of Singapore, provided these demands are not made on the assumption that if these are not acceded to, then merger should be scrapped and we should revert to the demand for full internal self-government minus the I.S.C. By all means let the Barisan Sosialis ask for better terms for Singapore than are contained in the White Paper, for we admit that the proposals in the White Paper are the result of a lot of give and take between Singapore and II other States. The Barisan Sosialis -

    An hon. Member: Secret deal!

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, talking about secret deals, we say publicly without any fear what we think. But lots of gentlemen on the other side vanish round about tea time or dinner time; lots of gentlemen go into a huddle. They even have to appoint I believe what is known as "Keeper of the Privy Script". One gentleman speaks and the other gentleman keeps on feeding him with scripts. I am using the word "privy". Sir, in a parliamentary sense.

    Sir, by all means let the Barisan Sosialis ask for conditions which they think would be more favourable. As I said, Sir, we concede that the White Paper proposals are the result of a lot of give and take between Singapore and 11 other States which constitute the Federation. And no doubt the Barisan Sosialis may feel that we should have given less and taken more, just as no doubt the Federation feel that they should have taken more and given less. But what we will resist, and all Malayan nationalists must resist, is the proposition that if we

Column: 532

cannot get merger on the terms demanded by the Barisan Sosialis, then we will fight for full internal self-government minus the I.S.C.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: You don't like freedom, huh!

    Mr Speaker: Order. Interjections are all very well if they are short and not too frequent. But the interjections coming from the Opposition Benches, the Barisan Sosialis section, are becoming too frequent.

    Mr Rajaratnam: In other words, Sir, there is a world of difference between putting forward demands with a view to getting the best possible terms for Singapore, and putting forward demands with a view to sabotaging merger and presenting us with the disastrous alternative of a self-governing Singapore.

    Sir, to judge by the speech made by the Member for Queenstown on Tuesday, the Barisan Sosialis appear to he determined that Singapore should not take the course of merger but the course o complete internal self-government. For example, Sir, it was reported in the Straits Times of 22nd November, 1961, that the Member for Queenstown after a long and passionate plea for merger and after shedding a lot of tears about how the two peoples are separated and how our blood brothers in the Federation have been inhumanly kept apart h3 the British colonialists - we shall come to the Barisan colonialists later, but, anyway, for the time being British colonialists - said [22nd November]:

    '"We must therefore reject the merger proposals. But it' it is possible for Singapore to form a confederation of Malaysia as an autonomous unit, then we shall welcome this advance...

    If none of these ways are open to us..."'

and I can assure you, Sir, that lots of gentlemen are working overtime to see that none of these ways are available -

    '"...then we should, in the discharge of our constitutional obligations, go to London in 1963 when the demand should he for complete internal self-government."'.

So, Sir, there we have it. After 7½ hours of oration and consultation, the Barisan Sosialis have reached the pre-determined conclusions on which it based its arguments - that if we cannot get merger,

Column: 533

then let us reject the White Paper proposals; let us reject the P.A.P. proposals for merger and bet us go back to internal self-government minus the I.S.C.

    Sir, the Member for Queenstown spent practically all his 7½ hours telling how terrible things would be for Singaporeans. Singaporeans, he said, would be second-class citizens. There would be apartheid. Singaporeans would be treated like social outcastes, not fit and not allowed to mix with our brothers in the Federation. Singaporeans, he said, would he treated like illegitimate citizens. Singaporeans would be treated as though they were suffering from some infectious disease. And all these, Sir, come from people who believe in merger! They were saying that merger is a wonderful thing, but if a P.A.P. type of merger comes about, then there would be apartheid, and Singaporeans would be treated like social outcastes, not fit to mix with their brothers in the Federation, and treated like somebody suffering from an infectious disease. This is the propaganda of men who want to sell the idea of merger. We know, Sir, that it is just the opposite, and that this fits in with our thesis - that they dread and are terrified of merger; not them but their mentors are terrified of merger. It is like those matchmakers who go around and, if they do not want someone to marry someone else, they say. "Yes, we are not in a position to get a very good girl. You know she has false teeth, a glass eye and she is wearing a wig!" They say. "Terrible, you know, but it is a very good thing. Singaporeans would be treated like outcastes. You would be treated like somebody who has got an infectious disease. Out with merger! Forward with the Barisan!"

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: That is your phoney merger.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, I have read and re-read what was published in the Straits Times, but I have not been able to acquire a full, voluminous version of his script obviously composed by many hands. All I could gather was that he spent 7½ hours telling us that Singaporeans would be treated like social out-castes, illegitimate citizens, people with

Column: 534

an infectious disease. But he did not produce one iota of fact or evidence to substantiate in what way under the White Paper proposals would Singaporeans be treated as outcastes, as people ridden with disease, as illegitimate children, and so on. He did not produce one single -

    Dr Lee Siew Choh rose -

    Mr Speaker: On a point of order?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Clarification, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: If the Minister will give way.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Yes, Sir, I am always willing to be clarified.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: May I ask the Minister if that is the reason why no mention was ever made of citizenship over Radio Singapore?

    Mr Speaker: Does the Minister understand that for clarification?

    Mr Rajaratnam: No. Sir, there is no reason to clarify that, because I do not know whether he had tried to compress into 10 or 15 minutes, something which took even him 7½ hours to recite in this Assembly. If certain things were left out, perhaps we have been merciful to the Member for Queenstown. Sir, he did not produce a single argument. In what way are we "outcastes"? Is there anything in the White Paper proposals to suggest that we are going to be treated as illegitimate children? When merger comes, if the Member for Queenstown should go to the Federation, is it likely that his status would be questioned? Would they ask him, "Legitimate or illegitimate?" Sir, he did not produce a single bit of evidence to justify his claim that merger under the White Paper proposals presented us with this terrifying aspect. But the only argument was that under the White Paper proposals, Singapore citizens cannot vote or stand for election in the Federation. Therefore. Singaporeans are illegitimate. That is the argument, Sir - the Member for Queenstown cannot stand for election in the Federation and it follows logically that Singaporeans are illegitimate: Singaporeans are disease-ridden.

Column: 535



    Anyway, Sir, if the fact that Singapore citizens cannot stand for election in the Federation makes Singapore citizens outcastes, make them second-class citizens, then on the same argument, Federation citizens also are outcastes, and second-class citizens. Therefore, what are the grounds that the Barisan Sosialis have for saying that the White Paper proposals discriminate against the people of Singapore?

    Sir, let me at this juncture remind Members of the Barisan Sosialis that this battle-cry of second-class citizens was also raised by certain people in the Federation when the Federation was struggling for independence. The same cry was raised. "Let us resist this new Constitution granting independence to the Federation because lots of people are going to be second-class citizens." And since the Members of the Barisan Sosialis claim to be on the side of history, to live with history, to sleep with history, they would do well to ponder over the fact that all the hue and cry over second-class citizens failed to halt the advent of Merdeka in the Federation. Today not even the P.P.P. leaders find it profitable to revive the question of second-class citizenship, simply because there was very little to this cry. So the Barisan Sosialis, who are never original (you can see. Sir, that they even have the same colours as the Party that they left; in fact, they have a circle for their symbol but they have not quite dared to complete it, so they put a star in) are merely repeating the tactics (well, there is no harm in repeating tactics) which were unsuccessfully tried in the Federation in the hope of halting independence. Today the Barisan Sosialis are also committed to halting independence through merger for Singapore. So like the gentlemen who failed in the Federation, they too are raising a hue and cry about second-class citizenship.

    Sir, in the course of his speech on Tuesday, the Member for Queenstown tried to create fears and doubts about merger in the minds of civil servants, contractors, students, businessmen and bus companies. This he did, not by saying in what way these categories of people

Column: 536

would suffer under the citizenship proposals contained in the White Paper, but by simply asking a number of questions and hoping to leave behind the impression that all these people would suffer under the White Paper merger proposals. For example, in the speech he said:

    'Would not this segregation and isolation of the people of Singapore from the people of the Federation lead to a further widening of differences that existed?

He did not say that it would. But he asked the question. He did not reply. He did not say, "Yes, that would be so." Then he asked,

    'What would the civil servants gain with merger?'

Again a question. No reply.

    'Would they get more opportunities for promotion in a wider service under the same terms existing, or under better terms?'

Again a question. No answer.

    'Would bus companies be allowed to operate freely on new routes in the Federation?'

Question - no answer.

    'Would they be treated equally with others?'

Question - no answer.

    'Would contractors get the same opportunities for business in the Federation as in Singapore?'

Question - no answer. And he went on in a similar vein dragging in workers, businessmen, Nanyang University students.

    Now, Sir, since he has asked questions -

    Mr Low Por Tuck: Answer them!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Rajaratnam: May I ask the Barisan Sosialis what would be the prospects for all these people if Singapore accepted the Barisan Sosialis' objective of full internal self-government for Singapore? Would it obviate segregation and isolation of the people of Singapore from the people of the Federation? Would civil servants be able to get more opportunities for promotion in Federal civil service if we had internal self-government? Would bus companies he allowed to operate a new route in the Federation if we got an internally self-governing Singapore? Would contractors get opportunities in the Federation if we

Column: 537

have full internal self-government for Singapore? Sir, it is quite clear what the whole purpose of that long series of unanswered questions is. Let me say this - the Member for Havelock asked. "Would you please answer?" All right. Let me answer.

    If we have full internal self-government as demanded by the Barisan Sosialis (and that actually is the real objective of the Barisan Sosialis), the prospects are open for bitter economic rivalry between the two territories. Singapore businessmen, Singapore civil servants, and contractors would not be able to survive economically in Singapore, let alone in the Federation. That is the logical outcome of the Barisan Sosialis' rhetorical questions - what will happen to this? What will happen to that? But we know what will happen to the Barisan Sosialis if there is full merger. That is the question to which they themselves do not know the answer.

    Sir, in any case, let me point out that at the present moment Singapore businessmen can and do do business in the Federation. So do Singapore contractors. In so far as there is preference for Federal citizens in the matter of Government jobs or contracts, may I point out that in Singapore too there is priority for Singapore citizens in the matter of certain types of Government jobs?

    In any case, Sir, under the Barisan Sosialis' type of complete merger, I can provide the answers to the questions that the Member for Queenstown asked. Singapore's civil servants definitely will suffer -

    An hon. Member: No!

    Mr Rajaratnam: - because they will have to accept the 4: 1 ratio that now obtains in the Federation.

    An hon. Member: Nonsense!

    Mr Rajaratnam: So too under the Barisan Sosialis type of merger they must accept the policy of preferential treatment for Malays in certain economic fields.
